headline.main: Clinton's Charity Confirms Qatar's $1 Million Gift While She Was at State Dept
headline.print_headline: Clinton's Charity Confirms Qatar's $1 Million Gift While She Was at State Dept

docs.snippet: The Clinton Foundation has confirmed it accepted a $1 million gift from Qatar while Hillary Clinton was U.S. secretary of state without informing the State Department, even though she had promised to let the agency review new or significantly incr...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Clinton Foundation has confirmed it accepted a $1 million gift from Qatar while Hillary Clinton was U.S. secretary of state without informing the State Department, even though she had promised to let the agency review new or significantly increased support from foreign governments.

headline.main: Column: Youth Football a Defining Issue With No Easy Answers
headline.print_headline: Column: Youth Football a Defining Issue With No Easy Answers

docs.snippet: Kevin Turner started playing football when he was 5. If his father had it to do over again, he might've insisted that his son wait a few years before taking up the game he loved so much, the game that that would eventually turn his brain to mush a...
docs.lead_paragraph: Kevin Turner started playing football when he was 5. If his father had it to do over again, he might've insisted that his son wait a few years before taking up the game he loved so much, the game that that would eventually turn his brain to mush and snuff out his life far too soon.

headline.main: The Closer the Race, the More Likely a Legal Challenge
headline.print_headline: The Closer the Race, the More Likely a Legal Challenge

docs.snippet: Donald Trump has notoriously refused to say he would accept a loss to Hillary Clinton in the Nov. 8 election, raising the prospect of a prolonged legal fight that could roil the nation. Legal battles over voting results are rarely successful but t...
docs.lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has notoriously refused to say he would accept a loss to Hillary Clinton in the Nov. 8 election, raising the prospect of a prolonged legal fight that could roil the nation. Legal battles over voting results are rarely successful but they do happen — most famously in 2000, when a 537-vote margin separated Democrat Al Gore and Republican George W. Bush in the must-win state of Florida. In that case, it took a Supreme Court ruling along party lines to resolve the dispute and make Bush president.
